text: How do you use visualizations to augment your machine learning process?
details:
I get that visualizations have traditionally been cast as the end-phase of the data analysis pipeline, and I certainly see how graphs and charts help to tell the story to the client/boss. However in my practice, visualizations play a really important role throughout my analytic process. I have found that visual diagnostics are particularly important for effective machine learning, especially since high-level Python libraries like Scikit-Learn make it so easy to instantiate and fit a predictive model. For me, the insight is a lot harder to get to without visualization tools. 

How critical are visualizations to the work of other data scientists? How do you use visual analysis to help navigate the data science pipeline? What libraries and tools do you routinely use to support your machine learning process (for example, for things like feature selection, model selection, model evaluation, and hyperparameter tuning)?

text: Is there a Python code base that can run linear, quadratic, logistic, and exponential regressions?

profile.biography: Faculty member at District Data Labs and the fool who wrote this web app.
profile.biography_rendered: Faculty member at District Data Labs and the fool who wrote this web app.

details:
As far as I know, Scikit-Learn can only do linear and polynomial regressions. The latter is achieved by using a pipeline to transform the feature space to include polynomial features, allowing us to perform quadratic regressions. We should be able to use the same technique to perform logistic and exponential regressions, right? I found some advice on this Stack Overflow question: [How to do exponential and logarithmic curve fitting](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3433486/how-to-do-exponential-and-logarithmic-curve-fitting-in-python-i-found-only-poly) — but it doesn't quite get to the answer. 

I'd like to use Scikit-Learn to do this, but am also open to other libraries; does anyone know how to run these types of regressions in Python? Moreover, what are the challenges and caveats with doing these types of regressions that might make these libraries avoid them?

text: What analytics can be performed on data modeled as a graph (network)?

profile.biography: Faculty member at District Data Labs and the fool who wrote this web app.
profile.biography_rendered: Faculty member at District Data Labs and the fool who wrote this web app.

details:
From a computer science perspective, data modeled as a graph (or network) wherein instances or entities are described as vertices with associated properties and their relationships are described as edges with properties is a very useful model for two reasons:

1. Many algorithms can be implemented in a more performant manner with graphs.
2. Small to medium graphs can be visualized and provide immediate insight. 

It would seem that graphs, therefore, would play an important role in data science and analytics; and surely tools like Spark's GraphX and Neo4j indicate that there is some interest. Unfortunately, when you explore actual _analytics_ that are native or at least employed on graphs, there are surprisingly few, and really nothing in the machine learning camp except page rank. 

My feeling is that this is just not as well publicized as other techniques; so if you are using or plan to use a graph in your analytics, what types of techniques, methods, or approaches are you using to derive insights or models?

text: What makes deterministic gender classification of text work but fail for other types of classification like sentiment?

profile.biography: Faculty member at District Data Labs and the fool who wrote this web app.
profile.biography_rendered: Faculty member at District Data Labs and the fool who wrote this web app.

details:
I'm routinely presented with an approach for text classification (particularly sentiment analysis) wherein a list of positive and negative words is curated, then counted in the text to make a determination of positive or negative sentiment. I stress that this is not a good approach because of the existence of sentences like these:

_"He was a no good, high-energy fella who bounced off the walls with incredible abandon, breaking a lamp in the process."_

We would probably say that this is a negative sentence, but replete with "positive" words like "good", "incredible", "high-energy" but only one negative word, "breaking". 

For this reason, it is important to use stochastic classification techniques like maximum entropy (logistic regression) with rich features like sentences parses. 

This reasoning does not hold true for gender detection, according to Neal Caren who did a [gender analysis of the New York Times](http://nbviewer.jupyter.org/gist/nealcaren/5105037) and which I reimplemented as a more Pythonic library in [Gender Words Fatale](https://github.com/bbengfort/gender-words-fatale). Here, gendered words like "grandmother", "heroine", "husband", etc. are used to create a gender score for the text. If I try to do the same thing with gender words as I did in the previous sentence (using negation), you can see that the text still stays the same gender: 

_"She was no lady, her tomboy antics led her to disguise herself as a man and join the army"_

The gender score is approximately 5 female and 2 male, making this more female gendered -- which is correct. Gender is a feature of language, particularly English - perhaps features like gender, tense, or cardinality are structural rather than implicit — and certainly we can use these as features in stochastic classification techniques.

So my question is for discussion — can we come up with a reason that deterministic techniques work for gender but not sentiment? Are there other classifications that would work in a similar manner? Perhaps we can debunk the idea that deterministic methods work for gender? I'd also be interested in seeing the gender words fatale project developed further and more extensively, or the creation of a gendered corpus for comparison.

text: Do you think Minimum Entropy is a good idea?

profile.biography: The DDL Admin is the Minimum Entropy chat bot and is here to help!
profile.biography_rendered: The DDL Admin is the Minimum Entropy chat bot and is here to help!

details:
Minimum Entropy was created when Rebecca noted that [Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/) can be a bit mean, and is certainly not the best place for beginners. Moreover, while there is a [Cross Validated Stack Exchange](http://stats.stackexchange.com/) and StackOverflow itself caters to machine learning questions in the programming domain, there is really no place for DDL and Georgetown students and members to get their questions answered.

Meanwhile in research land, Ben had already been working on a Question and Answer system called [Kyudo](https://github.com/mclumd/kyudo). We figured that we could easily adapt Kyudo to create a new internal question and answer site, similar to Stack Overflow and [Quora](https://www.quora.com/), but specific to our domain and questions. Minimum Entropy was launched. 

So the question is: do you think this is a good idea? Please be sure to express why or why not in your answer, any feedback would be very appreciated!
